body.div: Making successful recipes begins with using ingredients in the correct amounts. And here’s an important tip: Measuring cups for dry ingredients and liquid ingredients are not interchangeable.

div.p: For ingredients such as flour and sugar, select a set of measuring cups from ¼ cup to 1 cup to accommodate all your dry measuring needs. The graduated sizes allow the set to nest one inside the other, saving space while in storage. Cuisipro Measuring Cups ($9.99) from Bed Bath & Beyond feature long handles and thick, flat rims for easy leveling.

Once dry ingredients are spooned into measuring cups until they’re overflowing, the ingredient should be leveled off until it’s even with the rim. A blunt-edge utensil, like the Ateco offset or straight spatula (starting at $3.50) from atecousa.net is just the tool for the job.

Liquid measuring cups are typically made from clear glass or plastic and include a pouring spout. Horizontal markings on the outside indicate volume level and should be checked at eye level. Zyliss ($24.99) from macys.com also feature measurement markings that can be read from the inside, eliminating the need view at eye level. A nonslip base helps prevent spills, too.
Jamie Oliver’s Magnetic Measuring Spoons ($6.99), sold on amazon.com, have built-in magnets to keep the spoons together so you don’t lose them in the kitchen drawer.

Look for sets with long handles and shallow spoons so they’ll easily fit into small or narrow jars. Cuisipro Stainless Steel Measuring Spoons ($15.87) from amazon.com are heavy-duty and feature a removable loop to keep them intact.
